fields:
Annual CO2 emmissions per capita: 

US: {{c1::16t CO2}}. 
UK: {{c2::5t CO2}}.
Kenya: {{c3::0.3t CO2}}.
A London - NY flight releases ~{{c1::1t}} of CO2
The production of a t-shirt takes ~{{c1::7kg}} of CO2e.
An average car produces ~{{c1::0.5kg}} of CO2e per mile.
Natural gas produces ~{{c1::0.5kg}} CO2e per kwh; coal is about {{c1::1kg}}.

A 10-minute hot shower uses (very roughly) ~{{c1::4kg}} CO2e

Treating the water: {{c1::1kg}} CO2e
Heating the water: {{c1::2kg}} CO2e
Electricity cost of running the shower: {{c1::1kg}} CO2e

Taking a bath uses about {{c2::twice}} this amount.

Sources:

https://www.aquatell.ca/pages/how-household-water-usage-contributes-to-co2-emissions
https://wint.ai/blog/the-carbon-footprint-of-water/

Old Growth / Primary Forests are almost always carbon sinks, because {{c1::basically none of them (with the possible exception of the Pacific Northwest) have achieved the theoretical maximum biomass}}.

Sources:

"Old-growth forests as global carbon sinks"
https://sci-hub.ru/10.1038/nature07276
Carbon is stored in forests in two major ways: {{c1::above-ground (i.e. trees)}} and {{c2::below-ground (i.e. soil)}}.

Soil is a surprisingly good long-term carbon store, and is a slowly-decomposing mix of {{c1::plant / animal detritus}} (which decomposes quickly) and {{c1::humus}} (which is the stable result of the former, and decomposes slowly).

Major disturbances to the soil (as when a forest is chopped down) cause {{c2::the soil to decompose faster}}, frequently resulting in {{c2::new growth forests being net carbon emitters}}.
a6762eaa0afc4a28a7f6650b2f27acc6-oa-1
a6762eaa0afc4a28a7f6650b2f27acc6-oa-2

Immediately, one ton of methane traps {{c2::100}} times as much as one ton of CO2. 

Over {{c1::20}} years, the methane traps about {{c2::80}} times as much heat as the CO2. 

Over {{c1::100}} years, the methane traps about {{c2::25}} times as much heat as the CO2.
CO<sub>2</sub> has a half-life in the atmosphere of about {{c1::120}} years; methane is about {{c1::10}} years.

Global CO2 emissions started rising around {{c1::1800}}, when they were about {{c2::30 million tonnes}} of CO2 annually.

There are now about {{c3::30 billion}} tonnes of CO2 annually.
{{c1::12}} plant species account for {{c1::75%}} of crop production.
9bde2b883eda44cda7b0004fe1b8ecae-oa-1
9bde2b883eda44cda7b0004fe1b8ecae-oa-2
9bde2b883eda44cda7b0004fe1b8ecae-oa-3
Nobody knows how much monocropping occurs in the US, but it is probably around {{c1::15%}} of crop production.
Source: Market-Driven Corn Monocropping in the U.S. Midwest

Potential externalities of monocropping include:

1) {{c1::Nitrate runoff}}
2) {{c5::Increased pesticide use}}

3) {{c2::Increased pest population}}
4) {{c3::Kills pollinators because of homogenous diet & pesticides}}

5) {{c4::More water use due to weaker topsoil}}
Nitrate runoff is bad because of {{c1::NO2 emissions (300x warming potential of CO2)}}, {{c2::algal bloom}} and {{c3::water contamination leading to health risks (rare, but bad)}}.

Downsides of pesticide use include:

1) {{c1::Increased resistance of pests}}

2) {{c4::Kills pollinators}}

3) {{c2::Water contamination affecting local areas (maybe bad for neighbour's tap water)}}

4)  {{c3::Farm worker health}}.
Farm workers in the US have a life expectancy of {{c1::49}} years.

Switching to organic farming drops food output per area by ~{{c1::40}}%.

The effect on GHG emissions would be: {{c2::direct emissions would decrease, but overseas land use change would mean that total emissions would go up.}}
Source: UK Organic Farming Paper

The three main aspects of organic farming are:

{{c1::Organic fertilizer instead of synthetic}}

{{c2::No pesticides}}

{{c3::Emphasis on crop rotation + companion planting}}

Globally, what are the main differences in crop yields and diversity between small & big farms?

Small farms have {{c1::slightly higher yields (unclear if weight-per-acre or value-per-acre)}}.

There is little difference in {{c2::GHG emissions}} and {{c2::profit}}

FYI, none of this is really true in the US: the relationship between big & small farms in the US is very different than in more agriculture-heavy countries.

Source: Higher yields and more biodiversity on smaller farms
It takes {{c1::20}} lbs of grain to make 1lb of beef.
US meat consumption is ~{{c1::250}} lbs per person, annually: this is #{{c2::2}} in the world!
{{c2::NEPA (the National Environmental Policy Act)}} is the foundation of {{c1::environmental law in the US}}, and was signed into law in {{c3::1970}}.
NEPA precipitated the creation of the EPA, the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, etc., and is often called the "Magna Carta of environmental law".

Unlike the more specific environmental laws that followed it, NEPA {{c1::doesn't actually provide environmental protections}}. Instead it does three things:

1) {{c2::Declares a national environmental policy in lofty language}}

2) {{c3::Directs federal agencies to follow that policy, and take environmental effects into account when making decisions}}

3) {{c4::Establishes a Council on Environmental Equality (CEQ) in the White House}}.

The most important part of NEPA is a subsection specifying that:

{{c1::"Major Federal action" significantly affecting the quality of the human environment requires a "detailed environmental impact statement"}}.
None of these terms are defined...
The mean preparation time for EISs finished in 2020 was {{c1::about 5 years}}.
Federal agencies can skip EISs if they issue a {{c1::Finding of No Significant Impact (FONSI)}}, which must be based on an {{c2::Environmental Assessment (EA)}}.
The EA requirement was created by the CEQ in 1978, and is not mentioned in NEPA.

The federal government finalized around {{c1::200}} EISs each year, whereas it finalizes over {{c2::10,000}} EAs.

So even though EAs are shorter, their cumulative burden is much greater.

Surprisingly many things constitute a 'federal action' under NEPA, notably including {{c1::permit granting and changing of regulations}}.

NYC's congestion pricing is a good example: {{c2::its roads are part of the National Highway System, so it needs approval from the Federal Highway Administration, which then requires an EA}}.

Projects can involve several NEPA reviews if {{c2::they require multiple agency approvals}}. An example geothermal development on federal land required {{c1::six}} NEPA reviews over 10 years:

1) To make the land available for leasing
2) To actually lease it
3) For basic site exploration
4) To dig exploratory wells
5) To actually develop the wells
6) To build the power plant and transmission lines, etc.

The mammalian biosphere is wildly human focused. By biomass (measured in weight of carbon):

Wild Mammals: {{c1::4%}}
Humans: {{c2::About 1/3}}
Livestock: {{c3::About 2/3}}
{{c1::80%}} of global biomass is in {{c2::plants}}, {{c1::10%}} in {{c2::bacteria}}, and only {{c1::0.4%}} in {{c2::animals}}.

Among animals, {{c1::arthropods}} and {{c2::fish}} take up most of the biomass.

Mammals and birds make up less than {{c3::10%}} of animal biomass.

{{c1::Arthropods}} are the {{c2::most dominant animal (by biomass)}}, and characteristics include:

1) {{c3::Invertebrates}}
2) {{c4::Shells}}
3) {{c5::Segmented bodies}}

Common examples include: {{c6::crustaceans, centipedes, insects, spiders}}.

Most Nazi medical research was useless, and the only systematic assessment of the maybe-useful parts comes from a {{c1::US Army Doctor, Dr Leo Alexander}}, based on Himmler's files.

The debate over whether it is ethical to use Nazi research traces to two people: {{c2::Dr Robert Pozos, a hypothermia researcher at Minnesota Med School}}, and {{c2::Arthur Caplan, head of the Minnestota Biomedical Ethics Centre}}. {{c2::Pozos & Caplan}} raised the issue in a local newspaper in {{c3::1987}}, starting a national conversation on the subject.

https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/the-ethics-of-using-medical-data-from-nazi-experiments#use

Pozos Story: https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1988-10-30-mn-958-story.html

The final time that Nazi Holocaust medical research was seriously discussed was at {{c1::Arthur Caplan}}'s conference in 1989: "The Meaning of the Holocaust for Bioethics".

His summary review basically concludes: "The two obvious sides disagreed on their two things", but notably a Harvard Med School cardiac surgeon named {{c2::Robert Berger}} made the case that {{c3::it was irrelevant whether it was ethical to use the research, because the research was basically useless}}, and also that the premature and disproportionate ethical debate has given the false, lionizing impression that Nazi science was {{c4::useful and evil}}, instead of {{c4::dog shit and evil}}.

Caplan Conference: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/214164446.pdf
Berger Article: https://jme.bmj.com/content/medethics/20/4/207.full.pdf
Around {{c1::45}} medical articles published since WW2 reference Nazi research, almost all of which are about {{c2::hypothermia (and reference the Dachau experiments)}}.
JSTOR Reference: https://www.jstor.org/stable/3561733?origin=crossref
In the studies where IF helped lose weight, it was mostly due to {{c1::reducing calorie intake}}. IF without CR probably doesn't reduce weight.
Ups And Downs Paper: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8749464/#emmm202114418-bib-0159

Intermittent fasting can improve brain function because periods of fasting increase levels of a protein called {{c1::BDNF, or Brain-derived neurotrophic factor}}.  This protein helps neurons grow and make new connections which supports {{c2::learning and memory}}.
This may help prevent Alzeimer's and Parkinson's

IF lowers levels of {{c1::insulin}} in the blood. This makes the body more sensitive to {{c1::insulin's}} effects and makes the body start using {{c2::fat stores}} since glucose uptake by cells can't happen because of low insulin.
Because IF mildly {{c2::stresses cells}}, it turns on repair processes in cells like mitochondrial health, {{c3::DNA repair}} and {{c1::autophagy}}.
Autophagy reuses cellular components and conserves energy.
Intermittent fasting increases levels of {{c1::adiponectin}}, which is a hormone that {{c2::reduces inflammation}}.
Higher adiponectin levels may help explain anti-inflammatory effects of IF.
One mouse study found that, {{c1::regardless of caloric intake}}, intermittent fasting {{c2::enhanced insulin sensitivity and reduced blood glucose levels}}.
This shows that it's not the caloric restriction aspect of intermittent fasting that confers its benefits

Reasons why, in human studies, early time-restricted feeding (eating window earlier in the day) shows better results than late TRF in terms of weight loss, insulin sensitivity, blood pressure, inflammation, and oxidative stress: 

1. eTRF better aligns with the body's {{c1::circadian rhythms}} and {{c1::metabolic cycles}}, which are primed for food intake earlier in the day. 

2. {{c2::Insulin sensitivity}} and {{c2::glucose tolerance}} decrease over the course of the day. Eating earlier maximizes them.

3. Late night eating can negatively impact {{c3::sleep quality and duration}}, which can have downstream effects on body weight, metabolism and health.
Mechanisms of lifespan regulation by calorie restriction and intermittent fasting in model organisms: https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/12/4/1194/pdf

2023 mouse study: 

Caloric restriction itself extended the lifespan by {{c1::10%}}.

When the fasting time was added, the lifespan was increased to {{c2::20%}}.

When the feeding time was aligned to the active period, the lifespan was further extended to {{c3::35%}}, demonstrating that when food intake is restricted to an appropriate time of the day there is an additional benefit to caloric restriction and fasting on lifespan.
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/jdi.14033
In mouse longevity, what is the relationship between intermittent fasting and caloric restriction?

They are independently important, and the most long-lived population does both.



Paper: "Fasting drives the metabolic, molecular and geroprotective effects of a calorie-restricted diet in mice"

The meta-analysis investigating "Does Zinc cure colds?" had patients taking >{{c1::75}}mg / day of {{c2::zinc acetate or gluconate lozenges}}.

Mean common cold duration fell by {{c3::33%}} for zinc takers, with {{c4::no significant}} difference between the salts.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5418896/

The GOAT of common cold research is {{c1::Harri HemilÃ¤}}, a public health researcher at the {{c2::University of Helsinki}}, who wrote the only good meta-analyses on Vitamin C and Zinc as anti-cold measures.

Vitamin C: https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/9/4/339/htm
Vitamin C: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/

Zinc: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5418896/

{{c3::1g / day}} of Vitamin C reduces cold instances by {{c1::50%}} for people {{c2::undergoing heavy physical activity (marathon runners, skiiers, etc)}}.

It has {{c4::essentially no}} effect on normal people.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/
Regular supplementation of Vitamin C doesn't affect {{c1::cold frequency}}, but reduces {{c1::cold length}} by {{c2::10%}} in adults and {{c2::20%}} in kids.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/
Children get colds approximately {{c1::twice}} as often as adults.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/

Regular supplementation of Vitamin C needs to be at least {{c1::1g / day}} to have cold-length-reduction affects. Only two trials have been done with higher doses, and they show {{c2::linear improvement}} up to {{c3::6g / day}}.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/

The most common digestive symptoms of excessive vitamin C intake are {{c1::diarrhea and nausea}}. Some people start to experience these above {{c2::2g / day}}, but people have also consumed {{c3::100g / day}} with no ill-effects.

https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/side-effects-of-too-much-vitamin-c#vitamin-c

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/

There are a bunch of studies of theraputic Vitamin C and cold duration, and they all contradict eachother. The strongest effect was found by giving {{c1::6g}} / day and starting treatment {{c2::within 24 hours of symptom onset}}, which reduced mean cold length by {{c3::50%}}.

Ultimately this is probably highly individual-dependent, but you should try it just in case it works for you.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8078152/
Vitamin {{c1::B12}} is the most common deficiency for vegetarians: it's found in {{c2::meat, dairy, and eggs}}.

Over a 20 year period, each additional portion of daily fruit or vegetable reduced mortality risk by {{c1::5%}}, up to around {{c2::5 portions}}. Most of this protective effect is due to decreased risk of {{c3::cardiovascular disease}} and {{c3::some cancers}}.
https://www.bmj.com/content/349/bmj.g4490

Vegetables have {{c1::about the same}} fiber per serving as fruit, but {{c1::more}} per calorie.

Fruits are slightly higher in {{c2::antioxidants}}, and a couple more studies have found health benefits from {{c3::vegetables}} than {{c3::fruits}}, but both are generally treated the same in research.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6506980/

Beyond "fiber", there are hundreds of different phytochemicals in fruits and vegetables. None of them are well understood, and the phytochemicals don't break down nicely across fruit / vegetable lines.

From a nutritional perspective, fruit is essentially {{c1::a sugary vegetable}} with a slightly different {{c1::nutrient profile}}. If you're worried about {{c2::overall sugar intake}} or {{c2::blood sugar spikes}}, maybe swap some in vegetables for some fruit.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6506980/

Zinc studies are fuzzy about whether the 75mg is the mass of {{c1::zinc salt}} or {{c1::elemental zinc}}, but they are usually reporting {{c1::elemental zinc}} mass.

In zinc {{c2::acetate}}, elemental zinc is about {{c3::one third}} of total mass.

Hemila did a follow-up RCT in 2020 to confirm the results of his zinc meta-analysis.

He found that {{c1::zinc did not help}}, and theorized this might be because:

{{c2::His zinc tablets dissolved too quickly (10 mins vs half an hour)}}
{{c4::Treatment should be at least 90mg of zinc (his patients actually took ~60mg)}}
{{c3::Treatment should be longer than 5 days (zinc patients got worse after their treatment stopped)}}
https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/bmjopen/10/1/e031662.full.pdf

Consuming over {{c1::50mg}} of zinc over a long period of time can interfere with {{c2::copper absorbsion and immune function}}.

Over a short period of time, it might cause {{c3::nausea / stomach pain}}

https://www.nutritionletter.tufts.edu/ask-experts/q-i-take-50-milligrams-of-zinc-daily-but-it-looks-like-you-should-take-only-40-milligrams-per-day-is-it-ok-to-continue-what-are-the-consequences-of-too-much-zinc/
